_prev_prog_3.Description:
Alkoxylation Process.



This process involves the use of two subject chemicals which are ethylene oxide (EO) and propylene oxide (PO).  These chemicals are stored in above ground storage tanks.  The raw materials EO and PO are batch transferred to reactors to make different products.  All safety interlocks are the same except that EO is now added to the batches through the new distributed control system (DCS)(logic control).  PHAs are conducted by product family.  For example, EO product, PO product, mix EO and PO, foamy stripping, powder addition, etc.  The latest PHA was conducted 9/13/12 covered all product families.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies



Vantage Specialty Chemical's (VSC) operates the facility in the safest possible manner and believes in being responsible corporate citizen and maintaining open, constructive dialogue with our neighbors.  These principles are an integral part of our corporate Policy.  We believe that sharing this information with our neighbors will help the community better understand how safely VSC operates. VSC's Environmental, Health and Safety Policy includes the following:  



Vantage Specialty Chemicals has the following Corporate Guidelines related to environmental, health and safety:

 

- Create a workplace free from occupational injuries and illnesses

VSC is committed to achieving safety excellence and promoting employee health and wellness. We manage our businesses with a belief that all accidents are preventable through proper training, work practices and vigilant attention. Accident prevention is a responsibility recognized and shared by all employees and all levels of management. 



- Prevent environmental incidents

Spills and accidental releases to the environment are unacceptable. Through careful planning and regular review of our facilities and operations, we seek to identify risks and proactively eliminate them.



- Ensure sustainable compliance, and go beyond compliance when necessary to protect human health and the environment

VSC's operations encompass a wide range of activities that are subject to many national, state and local regulations and standards. The company has also established its own policies that support and, in some cases, are more stringent than the regulations. To achieve sustainable compliance, we continuously monitor our operations and the changing legal requirements and address any situations that may compromise our ability to comply. We also establish timely training and effective management systems to ensure that Petroferm management and employees understand and co

ntinuously comply with applicable regulations and policies.



- Focus on prevention of pollution as part of our total productivity improvement process

VSC routinely evaluates methods to prevent pollution, improve resource utilization effectiveness, and generate less waste material. We also strive to reuse or reclaim materials to the greatest extent economically feasible, to minimize the amount of waste requiring disposal. While this prevention approach is preferable, some amount of after-the-fact treatment of wastes is required in our manufacturing processes. We are committed to operating waste management and pollution control equipment to minimize environmental impacts.



VSC Gurnee Site implements these policies through site-specific programs and procedures.



2. The facility and the regulated substance handled



VSC uses two (2) RMP regulated chemicals: ethylene oxide and propylene oxide as raw materials.  These chemicals are used to manufacture surfactants.  The end products of the Gurnee site using the RMP chemicals as raw materials are used for personal care, food additives and automotive coatings.  



3. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps



To prevent accidental releases, this facility complies with EPA's Risk Management Program, OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard and the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care Process Safety Code. The facility's PSM program serves as the RMP Prevention Program.  The Prevention Program describes the policies and procedures in place to prevent and address accidental releases; these include Employee Participation, Process Hazard Analyses, Operating Procedures and Safe Work Practices, including Hot Work; Training, Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Contractors, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



The site uses a mix of control equipment, procedures and processes, and work practice controls to reduce the risk

of releases of the subject chemicals.  These include:



a. A distributed control system (DCS) for process control which reduces the risk of an accidental release and responds automatically to prevent and/or mitigate the impact of a release in the event of a malfunction or unexpected event such as a power failure. A separate program logic controller (PLC) continuously monitors process safety parameters on equipment and activates controls to bring operations into a safe mode if parameters are exceeded; and,



b.  Emissions control devices, including the site's main scrubber which capture emissions of ethylene oxide and propylene oxide from the manufacturing process and transform the emissions into innocuous chemicals which are routed to off-site treatment and disposal;



c.  A wastewater pre-treatment system which transforms the ethylene oxide and propylene oxide before discharge to the North Shore Sanitary District's wastewater treatment plant; and, 



d.  A fugitive emissions and a leak detection program to detect leaks and fugitive emissions before they become a problem.



4. Five-year accident History



In February 2010 the facility experienced a propylene oxide excursion when catalyst was left out of the reactor preventing the product from reacting. Several attempts were made to troubleshoot the reaction with PO being vented to the scrubber and new PO added. This action overcharged the scrubber capacilty with an estimated 9,500 pounds of PO. An estimated 2,740 pounds PO was discharged from the scrubber to the atmosphere.  Lab testing for catalyst before the oxide addition was added to the process operating instruction to prevent this from reoccurring.



5. Emergency Response Program



This facility has an emergency response plan that is coordinated with the community plan.  Hazmat team members are trained and participate in drills regularly. Annual drills are conducted with local municipal responders. Employees are trained how to identify an emergency an

d how to appropriately respond. There is an alert system at the site that is used to notify all employees of an emergency and the need to take action. There are layers of protection and redundant process control systems that will prevent or reduce the severity of a release.



The LEPC Coordinator for the county has been advised that the site is covered by the RMP regulations, has taken a tour of the facility, and maintains regular communication with the site.





6. Planned changes to improve safety



Processes are routinely changed to improve safety as a result of employee safety programs that include monthly safety meetings, daily preshift safety talks, employee process and safety training program, site safety steering committee with subcommittees that include  observation and suggestion programs, incident investigation and corrective action programs, workplace audits and inpsection programs, process safety, and safety awareness. Prevented maintenance programs continue to be utlilized to identify equipment that need to be repaired/replaced to maintain safe operations.
